awd_titl_txt: The Double Bind of Race and Gender:  A Look into the Experiences of Women of Color in Engineering
awd_abstract_narration:
This project addresses three major project interests of National Science Foundation's Broadening Participation of Engineering program: (a) analyzing and understanding the problem of poorly sustained participation in engineering across underrepresented demographic groups; (b) identifying structural inequalities and biases within educational and workforce systems that may influence engineering persistence; and (c) examining insufficient access to support systems and social networks that raise career awareness about different engineering pathways among underrepresented groups. More importantly, the project has the ability to provide the foundational data to evaluate the cumulative effects of women of color's double bind experience of race and gender in engineering and provide meaningful evidence of how disadvantage accrues over time. Further, the new knowledge generated from this project possess great potential in providing directions to engineering faculty and practitioners on how best to promote diversity and inclusion in engineering, where both diversity and inclusion remain a persistent challenge. 

Using intersectionality as the guiding theoretical framework, the project focuses on improving the engineering interests and experiences of women of color for the purpose of broadening participation. A predominantly qualitative research methodology is being used to pinpoint the obstacles that women of color have to overcome in engineering. The investigators are using the data to develop a framework and model that women of color can use to overcome challenges that they might face in engineering and other STEM disciplines.
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

inst.inst_name: Board of Regents, NSHE, obo University of Nevada, Reno
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: BOARD OF REGENTS OF THE NEVADA SYSTEM OF HIGHER ED

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Board of Regents, NSHE, obo University of Nevada, Reno

por.por_cntn:
The project addressed the overall research question: “How does the double bind of race and gender impact the experience of women of color in engineering?” Women of color (WOC) in particular, are often absent in academia, industry, and multiple levels of leadership roles, thus representing tremendous untapped human capital at every level. It is important that educators understand experiences of WOC and what is needed to improve their experiences. To explore this important topic, we have been working on the following goal and research questions:

Goal:  To understand how women (self-identified), including women of color, negotiate their multiple identities in the context of the normative STEM culture and define the “double bind” from an intersectionality perspective. 

RQ 1: How do women of color negotiate their multiple identities in the context of the normative STEM culture and define the “double bind” from an intersectionality perspective? 

RQ 2: What critical incidents, activities, or relationships influence the success (e.g. retention, performance, and contextual competence) of WOC and overcoming the “double bind” in STEM?

In addition we were able to add the following RQs to the study

RQ 3: What patterns or themes emerge in the participant’s characterization of their intersecting identities?

The STEM and engineering education community must do more to attract and retain WOC to enhance our field and our efforts for broadening participation in engineering. The study generated the following outcomes:

1) The project team has produced one published manuscript, three conference paper, and several manuscripts under development with submission targets over the next year. Future papers will include: (1) the  latent class analysis of survey data (2 sets), (2) co-PI Mendenhall will lead a paper exploring racialized microaggressions that emerged within the data set and provide evidence of how they occur within engineering , (3) multiple papers (3-4) will be required to discuss the four groups of qualitative codes that were developed in the codebook, (4) Both Cincinnati and UConn have survey and interview data that we will need to publish, (5) once each site has completed it’s analysis we will do a comparison analysis to identify commonalities and difference across the sites, and (6) Dr. Tsugawa is leading a paper on WOC teaming experience.

2) The research team worked collaboratively to develop manuscripts as PI Cross consulted the team on ways to separate data for multiple manuscripts under development. 4 campuses have been involved as study sites for the project. This includes the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign, the University of Cincinnati, the University of Connecticut, and the University of Nevada Reno. Over the course of the project 8 graduate trainees and 1 post doc were involved at the other study sites. 

3) The study applies an intersectional, Womanist framework to illuminate the experiences of WOC in engineering. Specifically, we focused on the intersection of race and gender to illuminate how WOC experience the “double bind” in STEM and demonstrate the analytical power of the Womanist theory and intersectionality within the context of engineering education research. A major product of our study was a validated survey and codebook that was used across multiple campuses. The survey and codebook allowed us to investigate how WOC negotiate their multiple identities in the context of the normative STEM culture.

4) Research Findings: Survey data (N ~450 students) i.)The participants reported high levels of identification with engineering and ethnic identity. ii.) The participants reported frequent interactions they consider as microaggressions. Additionally, the participants reported high levels of anxiety and depression based on the provisional diagnosis scoring. Based on our results, we recommend that the engineering education community must do more to improve racial climate, reduce gender and racial microaggressions, and create inclusive educational spaces to ensure the full participation of these students. For example, we need research to verify if mental health resources that specialize in WOC may be needed specifically for the STEM environment.

5) From the qualitative data, we found i.) WOC experience a double standard because they must react in different ways to protect themselves and survive in this chilly climate. ii.)     To be recognized as an engineer, WOC must adapt to social norms that are not their own to stay engaged with the engineering community while maintaining their own agency and sense of racial identity. Based on our results we recommend the engineering community continue developing inclusive spaces where WOC can thrive and establish safe spaces filled with individuals they can confide in within their engineering education. Additionally, we recognize the need to educate faculty, administrators, and other academic leadership on research-based strategies to identify and call out situations involving bias and discrimination in addition to training for faculty and staff on provide psychological safety within the education environment.

 

  

 

 

  

 


Last Modified: 11/04/2021
Modified by: Kelly J Cross

Based on our results we recommend the engineering community continue developing inclusive spaces where WOC can thrive and establish safe spaces filled with individuals they can confide in within their engineering education.
